awd_titl_txt: Modeling Tumor Invasion with Spheroids Embedded in Extracellular Matrix
awd_abstract_narration:
Over the past decade, much experimental work has focused on how stiffening and fiber alignment in the tissue around a tumor can transform the carcinoma into a more aggressive and invasive phenotype. On the theory side, there has been recent progress on modeling strain-stiffening transitions in fiber networks, as well as modeling single-cell migration through fiber networks. However, cellular-based models have yet to describe how large collections of cells interact with surrounding tissue, and therefore cannot predict observations such as cellular streams that leave a tumor collectively, for instance. One possible reason for this surprising theoretical gap is that modeling cell-ECM interactions requires a framework that simultaneously describes cellularized and acellularized tissues as well as a (possibly convoluted) interface between them, with a minimal number of directly observable parameters, such as cell shape and fiber network microarchitecture. New experimental techniques will allow the PIs to perform measurements that can not only be directly tested against the modeling but will help guide the modeling as well. In the clinical treatment of cancers like carcinomas, it is difficult to identify biomarkers that correctly predict the aggressiveness of a tumor in an individual patient. It is also difficult to quantify how the microenvironment of a tumor might alter the prognosis for a particular patient. The research proposed here will address these two problems using ideas that are complementary to the ones typically being explored in cancer biology labs, by identifying how experimentally-accessible metrics correlate with tumor invasiveness and perhaps even patient outcomes. The PIs suggest that structural biomarkers such as cell shape and fiber alignment may work together to specify tumor invasiveness. To broaden the participation in the growing interdisciplinary fields of tissue mechanics and active matter, the PIs will establish an inter-departmental and inter-university soft matter-biology journal club and will devise a short course on “the soft matter physics of cancer” to disseminate at venues such as the Boulder school for condensed matter and other summer schools. These endeavors should help generate interest among a new generation in important problems at the intersection of soft matter and biology.

The PIs will use theoretical and experimental tools to quantify the interactions between a multicellular tumor spheroid and its extracellular matrix (ECM) environment. Their hypothesis is that bulk rheology and interfacial energies place strong constraints on how the spheroid and ECM interact to stabilize or destabilize the tumor boundary and, thereby, govern tumor invasiveness. Their prior theoretical work demonstrates that both vertex models for dense, cellularized tumors and fiber network models for the acellular extracellular matrix (ECM) exhibit similar rigidity transitions driving their respective rheologies. Additional theoretical work has carefully characterized the surprising dynamics of interfaces between two different tissue types in these models. Finally, they have developed a powerful experimental technique to probe the mechanical interactions between single breast tumor cells and extracellular matrices. This technique will now be applied to multicellular tumor spheroids. Therefore, the PIs are well-poised to develop testable predictions for tumor invasion in this model system. They first will theoretically and experimentally study how the rheology of the tumor spheroid, coupled to the ECM, via a mechanosensitive interfacial energy modulates the competition between cell-cell adhesion and cell- ECM adhesion to deform a stable tumor-ECM boundary. They will then investigate how cell growth, relevant at longer time scales, affects this competition to lead to deformable and propagating, stable tumor-ECM boundaries. Finally, they will explore under what conditions the spheroid-ECM boundary ultimately destabilizes at the individual and/or multicellular scale to lead to invasion of the surrounding tissue.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
What biophysical mechanisms drive cancer cells in a tumor to invade the surrounding extracellular matrix? Given that the surrounding extracellular matrix is a complex environment, containing not just a crosslinked network of collagen fibers but other cell types, such as immune cells and cancer-associated fibroblasts to name a few.  Given this complexity, in vitro tumor spheroids embedded in a collagen fiber network provide a key experimental testing ground to begin to determine what biophysical mechanisms drive cancer cells in a tumor to invade its surroundings and, therefore, spread to other parts of the body. With such an experimental system, researchers have found, for example, that cancer cells are less likely to break out of a tumor spheroid with increasing collagen density. To be able to predict such outcomes, computational modeling lags significantly behind experiments, especially concerning biophysical forces, and thus unable to provide experiments with guiding principles. One of the major outcomes of this project is a new three-dimensional computational model for embedded spheroids that can be used to generate predictions for experiments. 

This new computational model consists of coupling a three-dimensional vertex model, which represents the cells in the spheroid as deformable polyhedrons that share faces, to a fiber network model, representing crosslinked collagen fibers. The coupling between the spheroid of cells and the fiber network consists of linker springs, denoting integrins that connect cells to fibers.  As these linker springs actively contract in a molecular clutch-like fashion, the fiber network remodels, or changes. With such a computational model, one can then predict how the collective properties of the spheroid affect the remodeling of the fiber network in terms of reorienting the fibers and/or densifying the fibers.  Understanding the fiber network remodeling is important for understanding how cells use the fiber network to break away from the tumor spheroid as they potentially move out into it.  

As for collective properties of the spheroid, by changing a parameter in the three-dimensional vertex model, namely the target shape index, one can toggle between fluid-like and solid-like spheroids. The computational model demonstrates that the solidity-fluidity of the spheroid significantly affects the remodeling of the fiber network. Specifically, fluid-like spheroids surprisingly displace the fiber network more on average near the vicinity of the spheroid than solid-like spheroids. Moreover, fluid-like spheroids radially reorient the fiber network more on average near the vicinity of the spheroid than solid-like spheroids. The differences in fiber network remodeling are the result of cellular rearrangements that emerge over time in the fluid-like spheroids, but not in the solid-like spheroids, to generate spheroid shape fluctuations lead to additional remodeling of the fiber network, which then leads to additional spheroid shape fluctuations. In other words, positive mechanical feedback emerges between the fluid-like spheroid and the fiber network to enhance fiber network remodeling. 

These computational results are qualitatively confirmed by experiments with fluid-like spheroids, consisting of MDA-MB-231 cancer cells, radially realigning the fiber network more than solid-like spheroids, consisting of MCF10A cells.  Computational-experimental comparisons will be studied more quantitatively in the near future.  The computational model also predicts that the emergent mechanical feedback between fluid-like spheroids and the fiber network occurs over a window of fiber network stiffnesses/densities, interestingly. And finally, the computational model predicts a change in cell shape index distribution given the overall spheroid shape fluctuations in the fluid-like case that has been confirmed in experiments comparing fiber network remodeling due to spheroids consisting of mouse embryonic fibroblast cells and their vimentin-null counterpart. All in all, this new computational model provides a big step forward in providing guiding biophysical principles for the pre-invasion stages of tumors embedded in extracellular matrices.  

This project also provided new insights into the mechanisms driving phase changes from solid-like spheroids to fluid-like spheroids in three-dimensions as well as extending the canonical two-dimensional vertex model to describe cell cross-sections that are not necessarily convex. Inspired by recent experiments, calculations predict that local, subcellular curvature at cell-cell interfaces can emerge in a subgroup of cells in response to the swelling of surrounding cells that decrease the available space of the subgroup. With this framework, one can explore a wider array of multi-cellular responses, such as embedded spheroids, to constraints in the surrounding environment. Finally, efforts towards multi-scale modeling of spheroids, and even organoids, began with this project to tie together the tissue scale with the chromatin scale, as cancer is a multi-scale phenomenon. 

Interdisciplinary training of physicists learning about biology and biologists learning about physics was a key broader impacts outcome for this project. Additionally, a now public code base for three-dimensional vertex modeling is helping to broaden interest in the computational modeling of the biophysics of cancer and multi-cellular structures more generally. On a larger scale, the link between biophysical modeling and in vitro cancer studies has been strengthened with this project. 

 

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 12/31/2024
Modified by: Jennifer Schwarz
